content:
Sure, for a rap verse in the style of The Notorious B.I.G, we could have a flow that is slow, smooth, and deliberate, with a focus on storytelling and wordplay.

Here's an example of a rap verse in the style of The Notorious B.I.G for "Grandma-ma":

Verse:
Listen up y'all, it's the grandma with the power
She's a hero, in the darkest hour
She's got a stick that's enchanted
With powers that'll leave you daunted
She's a savior, in the streets we call her "Grandma-ma"
She's taking care of her community, like Obama
She's got the skills, she's got the flow
She's the one that you should know
She's the grandma that's here to save the day
She's the one that's here to make you say "Hooray!"

This verse has a flow that is slow, smooth, and deliberate, with a focus on storytelling and wordplay, like the Notorious BIG style. The verse also incorporates elements of the story and the characters, while still maintaining the comedic tone of the story.

Keep in mind that this is just an example, and you can always experiment with different rhymes, flows, and wordplay to find the one that aligns with your artistic vision and the tone of the story.
